texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Diacritics  are all of the small things that are added on, above, or below certain characters in various languages. Some examples include tildes (ñ), accents (á), or other marks (š). These marks are little hints that help you know how to pronounce a word properly (and they sometimes change the definition of a word entirely).
texts.text: Diacritics  are all of the small things that are added on, above, or below certain characters in various languages. Some examples include tildes (ñ), accents (á), or other marks (š). These marks are little hints that help you know how to pronounce a word properly (and they sometimes change the definition of a word entirely).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: They are often skipped by non-native language speakers, and sometimes even by native speakers, but I have done my best to make a habit of including them when I can.
texts.text: They are often skipped by non-native language speakers, and sometimes even by native speakers, but I have done my best to make a habit of including them when I can.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Pronounciation can change drastically with a certain mark. For example, a common Czech name is Tomaš. The š on the end makes a  sh  sound insead of a the normal  sss  sound.
texts.text: Pronounciation can change drastically with a certain mark. For example, a common Czech name is Tomaš. The š on the end makes a  sh  sound insead of a the normal  sss  sound.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In Spanish, the word for Spain is España. The ñ has a  n  sound followed by a yah  sound. If you leave off the ñ, you end up with a sound like  ana  on the end instead of  an-yah .
texts.text: In Spanish, the word for Spain is España. The ñ has a  n  sound followed by a yah  sound. If you leave off the ñ, you end up with a sound like  ana  on the end instead of  an-yah .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Leaving out diacritics can also lead to terrible results, such as a famous Spanish mistake:
texts.text: Leaving out diacritics can also lead to terrible results, such as a famous Spanish mistake:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Mi papá tiene cincuenta años
texts.text: Mi papá tiene cincuenta años

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Mi papa tiene cincuenta anos
texts.text: Mi papa tiene cincuenta anos

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This could  obviously  lead to some confusion. 🤭
texts.text: This could  obviously  lead to some confusion. 🤭

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: First attempts (failures)
texts.text: First attempts (failures)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: At first, I found myself going to  online character maps  and I would copy/paste the character I wanted. Typing in Spanish quickly became painful with the constant back and forth to copy certain characters.
texts.text: At first, I found myself going to  online character maps  and I would copy/paste the character I wanted. Typing in Spanish quickly became painful with the constant back and forth to copy certain characters.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I knew there had to be a better way.
texts.text: I knew there had to be a better way.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: AltGr
texts.text: AltGr

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After some research, I found that there are some keyboards with a special Alt key on the right side of the space bar called the  AltGr  key. It's a special modifier key that lets you type characters that are not easy with your keyboard layout.
texts.text: After some research, I found that there are some keyboards with a special Alt key on the right side of the space bar called the  AltGr  key. It's a special modifier key that lets you type characters that are not easy with your keyboard layout.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Luckily, you can tell your computer to pretend like you have an AltGr key to the right of the keyboard and you get access to all of the international characters via key combinations.
texts.text: Luckily, you can tell your computer to pretend like you have an AltGr key to the right of the keyboard and you get access to all of the international characters via key combinations.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: For Linux, you can run this in any terminal:
texts.text: For Linux, you can run this in any terminal:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: setxkbmap us -variant altgr-intl
texts.text: setxkbmap us -variant altgr-intl

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I add this command in my
texts.text: I add this command in my

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ~/.config/i3/config
texts.text: ~/.config/i3/config

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: for i3:
texts.text: for i3:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: exec_always --no-startup-id "setxkbmap us -variant altgr-intl"
texts.text: exec_always --no-startup-id "setxkbmap us -variant altgr-intl"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Most window managers give you the option to change the keyboard layout for your session in the window manager settings.
texts.text: Most window managers give you the option to change the keyboard layout for your session in the window manager settings.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In GNOME, open  Settings , click  Region & Language , and click the plus (+) below the list of layouts. Choose  English  and then choose  English (US, alt. intl.)  from the list. You can switch from layout to layout in GNOME, but AltGr works well for me as a default.
texts.text: In GNOME, open  Settings , click  Region & Language , and click the plus (+) below the list of layouts. Choose  English  and then choose  English (US, alt. intl.)  from the list. You can switch from layout to layout in GNOME, but AltGr works well for me as a default.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Trying it out
texts.text: Trying it out

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Once you have AltGr enabled, here are some quick things to try:
texts.text: Once you have AltGr enabled, here are some quick things to try:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AltGr + Shift + ~, release keys, press n:
texts.text: AltGr + Shift + ~, release keys, press n:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AltGr + ', release keys, press a:
texts.text: AltGr + ', release keys, press a:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AltGr + Shift + ., release keys, press s:
texts.text: AltGr + Shift + ., release keys, press s:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AltGr + s:
texts.text: AltGr + s:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Take a look at  AltGr  on Wikipedia for lots more combinations.
texts.text: Take a look at  AltGr  on Wikipedia for lots more combinations.
